title: What steps should I take to help me get into the United States Air Force Academy? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s been 40 years since I went through the process, but I don’t think it has fundamentally changed in that time. Other folks here have given good answers, so I won’t repeat what they’ve said. I do have a couple of things I’d like to emphasize, however. In order to be considered for appointment, one has to have a nomination. Congressmen and the Vice President all have a limited number of slots available at any given time. In order to get a nomination through one of these sources, you essentially have to convince the person that you deserve to have one of their slots. Politics can play, though I was aware of only one classmate that appeared to get his nomination through pure political connections. I was fortunate enough to be the son of a retired Air Force officer who owned a small newspaper in the district of one of the most powerful men on Capitol Hill at that time. And I single-mindedly pursued that appointment from elementary school. If you can’t make that work, and you are the child of a retired military member, you have an automatic Presidential nomination. One of my classmates was the son of the legendary USAAF/USAF ace, Gabby Gabreski. There are a number of other categories, including children of deceased, missing, and disabled veterans, Medal of Honor winners (that’s essentially an automatic appointment if you can pass the entrance requirements), and their are nominations available for Air Force enlisted personnel and ROTC students. One other avenue that isn’t talked about a lot is a sports “scholarship.” If you are particularly good at a sport, the Academy will go to great lengths to recruit you and get you in. I don’t know exactly how far that extends (I wasn’t an athletic recruit), but the Academy has some highly successful sports teams, and that’s no accident. One last point. I didn’t have perfect grades, I wasn’t the best athlete, and I went to a very small high school. As it happens, admissions emphasis changes from year to year. My year, they emphasized extracurriculars. The next year, the pendulum swung in favor of academics. I also had a hard time finding anyone else among my classmates who had planned to go to the Academy years in advance - some hadn’t considered it until a few bare months before entrance. So if you feel like you’re a little late in the process, don’t despair. I didn’t make it on my first try, and did a year in college and ROTC before I got my appointment. Personally, I’d say persistence and focus are great assets.

Without knowing where you are in life (high school, college, enlisted, etc), it’s difficult to give you an answer specific to your situation. This is a generic checklist of things you can do assuming you’re coming straight from highs school. I can’t speak to the other entry paths. Start taking steps freshman year of high school. Make your goals known and get yourself on the radar of influential people. You’ll need these people to write you letters of recommendation when the time comes.Develop relationships with local politicians. If you do things right, this will just happen naturally. Again, you’ll want letters of recommendation from these people when the time comes.Find a grad or an LO to mentor you through the process. This will not be fun. Asking people for help when they get nothing in return is a hard sell. Do it anyway. You need someone to keep you on path over the years.Your highest priority is to get your grades as close to a 4.0 as possible. Bs should be considered unacceptable. A perfect 4.0 might be unattainable but it doesn’t matter. Make it your goal anyway. You’re going to be competing against people that get As in their sleep so you might as well get into the habit of high academic performance. You’ll need these habits if you get an appointment.Play a sport. Doesn’t matter if you make varsity or not. The point is to increase your physical fitness. You’ll have to play some sort of sport out there anyway so, again, it’s good to get into the habit now.Do something that demonstrates you have leadership potential. Join a military youth leadership organization. JROTC, CAP, Young Marines, Sea Cadets. Branch doesn’t matter. If you don’t have access to these organizations, you have options. Boy Scouts are usually everywhere. There are also civic youth organizations. School clubs are also useful along with student government. Make sure you rise in these organizations. By the time you apply, you want to be able to show that you’ve already lead people.STUDY FOR THE ACT/SAT. Most of the sections will depend on your upbringing and quality of your school district (exposure to English, literature, and science), but the math section is straight up memorization. You just have to practice. Start taking the standardized test junior year. You can take them more than once. Speaking of junior year….Junior year is when you really need to step it up. During that year, you’ll want to apply for Summer Seminar. This is another “get on the radar” step.This is a bonus step and not everybody can or even needs to do it. But if you are interested in flying, start taking flying lessons and try to at least solo before graduation if not fully gain your pilots license.If you join Scouts or CAP, make sure you make Spaatz or Eagle Scout by December of your senior year.When senior year finally rolls around, start the process as soon as you can. The application process is long. It takes months and has numerous steps that have to be coordinated over long distances and you’re one file in 10,000. Once you do, stay on top of things. I don’t care how good the tech is now. This is the military. There is an almost 100% chance you’ll fall through the cracks on something.Finally, as a general rule, no matter what you do, be awesome. Sounds cheesy but, if you land an appointment, you’ll be going to school with literally the best this country has to offer. You’re going to need to stick out from the crowd in some manner.

I have listed 5 points that you must meet: 1-Very good grades: B+ to As 2-Math and science classes. Good grades again 3-Clean record, no diciplinary issues on your record. In fact be a leader, be in the top 10% of your class in every field. 4-Athletic ability. Get on a team. Be in really good shape. If you can’t pass the PE requirements, you won't get in. Work out every day. How fit? can you run 3 miles in 12 minutes? 5-This is VERY Important: Find out who your congressman/woman is. Volunteer to work in their district office. Then when you are ready to apply, you can ask for a letter of recommendation. Better that you are not a stranger, that way you will get a good letter that will be more personal than a form letter. Extra credit: show some desire, focus and dedication; see if you can join the Civil Air Patrol Cadet Corps or if available at your school, JAFROTC. Good luck.

I'm a USAFA graduate, class of 1984. Many of these pieces of advice are correct but some are not. Yes you must be well qualified as an applicant, that's first and foremost. But the involvement of the congressman or senator isn't a letter of recommendation, it's actually an appointment to the academy. While they do have the power to simply appoint anyone of the proper age, almost all the politicians make a list of 10 or more applicants and let the academies themselves rank them and make the final choices. I didn't know anyone who "got in good" with their representative to garner one of these appointments. I'm not saying it's impossible, but it's not the norm at all. Focus on being the best candidate, the political angle will solve itself. I think playing politics isn't worth the time. You will have to pass a physical fitness test to get in, but it's pretty easy. Later you'll have much harder tests to pass as a cadet/midshipman. If you're serious about USAFA I'd be glad to answer further questions. Scott Hypocrophobe@gmail.com Surgery@usa.net

Enlist first. The AFA reserves 80 slots per class for enlisted Airmen. All you have to do is meet the minimums; you aren't really competing against all the direct entries. Plus, if admissions isn't totally satisfied with your academic potential they can send you to the Prep School for a year. If you don't want to do that then you'll need an appointment. If you don't already have a connection to your representative(s) then just start bothering them nonstop until they respect your grit or want to get rid of you or something.  You could also try getting recruited for a sport.

You could have guessed this: Go to www.academyadmissions.com. Requirements, criteria, procedures, etc., change, and that website is the right place to start. I taught there, and it is a wonderful place that will provide you an outstanding education and experiences, especially the summer activities away from the Academy, that you cannot even imagine! And at the end, best of all, a terrific career! What about West Point or Annapolis? In most important ways, the same.

Start running to build up your endurance. A mile three times a week with at least a day in between. Slowly work up to three miles over months. Look at the physical fitness test. Start practicing that. Push ups, sit ups, and pull ups every night. Get a letter in a sport. Buckle down on academics. You need As and Bs. Nothing less. If you get in, buy a used copy of Contrails online. That’s the Cadet handbook. Memorize everything in it so that you can say it on command. It’s easier if you get a jump on it when you have oodles of time than when you are under the gun at the Zoo. Find a cadet and talk to them so you get an idea of the crap you are getting into.

A person has to be appointed by one of that person’s two United State’s senators to any of the United State’s military academies, including the US Air Force Academy. I recommend that you call the offices of both of your state’s United States Senators and get each Senator’s office to send you their package on what each senator requires for a person to be considered for appointment to the U S Air Force Academy or each of the US military academies. Good Luck!

Well it starts shortly after you start High School, getting good grades and extra circular activities. Then you have to apply to/interview with one or more of the 3 possible members of Congress that has to nominate you. Your state’s 2 US Senators and your Congressman(House of Representative). Each of these 3 can only nominate 1 person to the US Air Force Academy.

That is like the old question, “How do you get to Carnegie Hall? Practice, Practice, Practice!” You do it by planning and preparing well ahead of application. It is not something you do as a fall back choice or spur of the moment decision. It takes both physical, mental, and educational preparation. You can start by going to: Air Force Academy and studying the process.

I am a junior in high school, with a 3.75 gpa in both my freshman and sophomore year. Up until now o haven’t done any co-curricular activities, but I am really trying to get as many as possible to increase my chances. I am currently applying for the NHS.

Biggest thing is getting sponsored. Without that, you won't get in.  Other than that, good grades and extracurricular activities. And find people that will give a good recommendation. Good luck. I and many others have made it - you can too.
I would say step one would be learning to research this question instead of expecting someone else to do it for you. If you can’t do that then you are not USAFA material.
You do not join, you compete for a nomination. Go to Air Force Academy for instructions.
To start: excellent grades, especially in math and sciences. Active in school activities, sports. Be a leader. Letters of recommendation from teachers and local congressmen.
